course.subject: LABU
course.name: Business Case Analyses
course.description: This course seeks to equip students with persuasive communication skills, both oral and written, through analyzing business cases and presenting solutions to problems identified. It provides students with a solid framework and hands-on practice to communicate persuasively and professionally in business settings. In presenting the case problem, analysis and recommendations, students learn to identify issues, develop and organize key ideas, and eventually to persuade the audience of the validity of the arguments and proposed actions. The course sharpens students' ability to explain and support ideas logically, coherently and cohesively using various techniques, to communicate clearly, concisely and accurately, and in appropriate tone and style. Through a range of learning activities involving reading, discussion, writing and making oral presentations, students also develop critical reading, critical thinking and problem solving skills as well as teamwork and leadership skills. For students who have this course as a program requirement.
course.prerequisites: CORE 1403 OR CORE 1404 OR LANG 1003 (prior to 2022-23)
course.exclusions: LABU 2051, LABU 2052

reviews.author: blue :)
reviews.comment_content:
During the add-drop period:
Mini case: California Wood Harvesting Co.
- Presentation (F2F)
(Not graded)

During the semester:
Case 1: WIYCR
- Presentation (Video recording)
- Recommendation Report
Case 2: Kitchen Best
- Presentation (F2F)
- Learning Portfolio

Group presentation formed by 4 ppl.
reviews.comment_teaching: Levi is a nice professor and the lessons are interactive. He is very helpful and guided us step by step when we wrote the recommendation report. He also offered us lots of advice during group discussions. Overall a very good professor.
reviews.comment_grading:
No Mid-terms or Finals.
Only 3 presentations in total throughout the semester. (The first one won't be graded, just a practice presentation)

The grading is good. Presentations are graded by: Excellent, Very good, Competent, ...). Around 80% of mine is very good and 20% is competent. But out of my expectation, the final grade is A.

A small reminder: Make sure you follow everything he says (PPT Slide, presentation structure, the recommendation report, and the learning portfolio) and you would get an A-range grade.
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload is low.

You only need to read the case before lessons. (And there's only 3 in total). Cases are around 15-20 pages long.

No homework/ take-home assignments in general, only one recommendation report. Levi would give you time in class to work on that. If you want to polish the essay but don't have enough time in class, you might need to spend some extra time working on it.

There are presentations, and you have time to prepare the ppt slides together with your groupmates in class (Levi would offer you suggestions in the meantime). You can also prepare scripts in class so no extra work is needed outside the classroom. However, if your group wants to do rehearsal beforehand (which is recommended), there would not be enough time in class.

reviews.author: kkklo
reviews.comment_content:
Assessment overview in chronological order:
1. Oral presentation 1: 12 mins, groups of 3 or 4 (20%)
2. Peer evaluation for oral presentation 1 (2%)
3. Writing task: individual, 1000 words max (28%)
4. Oral presentation 2: 12 mins + 4 mins Q&A, groups of 3 or 4 (28%)
5. Peer evaluation for oral presentation 2 (2%)
6. Online assignments: online quizzes based on case readings â€‹(4%)
7. Discussion skills: peer evaluation for oral presentations 1 and 2 (8% - 4% x 2)
8. Learning portfolio (8%)

Attendance is required.
reviews.comment_teaching: Nick's a great teacher. He's approachable and his teaching is understandable. From his powerpoints, you will be able to gauge what he is hoping to see in your presentations. He's flexible in terms of class logistics (e.g. order of presentation), and he always offers consultation sessions for each group before each final presentation. And on the fun side, he sends out weekly emails recommending music he enjoys listening to!
reviews.comment_grading: Nick's a fair grader. He makes sure you know what he is looking for and it's very easy to clarify in class. For the writing task, he shows written examples of what is good and bad; for the presentations, he shows past videos of groups so the standard is clear.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is totally tolerable. If you're a comfortable and confident speaker, you might find this a fun class, especially with Nick. You will have to find time outside to go through your presentations with groupmates and record your performance though (for the first presentation).

reviews.author: Yannes Kwok
reviews.title: Reg Ivan Yung!!
reviews.comment_content: There are two cases for the course. For the first one, we are required to do a group presentation and for the second one there are both a group presentation and an individual report.
reviews.comment_teaching: He teaches well while being chill at the same time. He is very willing to help after office hours, you can always email him and he will try his best to offer help.
reviews.comment_grading: The grading is very nice, just follow his instructions and hand in work on time --> you will be able to get an A-range grade.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is alright. There may be things to prepare before each lesson (e.g. case readings, sharing on case analysis), but the amount is acceptable.
